xhtml:div.label:
Beginning of a subsequence in your sequence (-b)?
Select the beginning of a subsequence from a larger sequence file. The smallest sequence that tacg can handle is 4 bases, 10 for the ladders map (-l). This allows analysis of primers and linkers.
End of a subsequence in your sequence (-e)
Form (or topology) of DNA (-f) Circular Linear

Degeneracy flag - controls input and analysis of degenerate sequence input (-D)?
FORCES exclusion of degens in sequence; only 'acgtu' accepted (0) Cut as NONdegen unless degen's found; then cut as '-D3' (1) Degen's OK; ignore in KEY, but match outside of KEY (2) Degen's OK; expand in KEY, find only EXACT matches (3) Degen's OK; expand in KEY, find ALL POSSIBLE matches (4)
The pattern matching is adaptive; given a small window of nondegenerate sequence, the algorithm will match very fast; if degenerate sequence is detected, it will switch to a slower, iterative approach. This results in speed that is proportional to degeneracy for most cases.

Codon Usage table to use for translation (-C) Standard Vertebrate Mitochondrial (1) Yeast Mitochondrial (2) Mold, Protozoan, and Coelenterate Mitochondrial and the Mycoplasma/Spiroplasma (3) Invertebrate Mitochondrial (4) Ciliate, Dasycladacean and Hexamita Nuclear (5) Echinoderm Mitochondrial Code (6) Euplotid Nuclear (7) Bacterial (8) Alternative Yeast Nuclear (9) Ascidian Mitochondrial (10) Flatworm Mitochondrial (11) Blepharisma (12) Chloro Mitochondrial (13) Trematode Mitochondrial (14) Scenedes Mitochondrial (15) Thrausto Mitochondrial (16)
Order the output by number of cuts/fragments (-c) Yes No

Output width (-w)?
The number is truncated to a # exactly divisible by 15 (-w 100 will be interpreted as -w 90) and actual printed output will be about 20 characters wider. Also applies to output of the ladder and gel maps, so if you are trying to get more accuracy and your output device can display small fonts, you may want to use this flag to widen the output.
Histogram output (-G) Horizontal X axis (X) Vertical Y axis (Y) Long output (L)

Step size in histogram?
N bases for which hits should be pooled (integer)

Controls the output for sequences (-i)?
No control ID line and normal output regardless of hits (0) BOTH ID line and normal output are printed ONLY IF there are hits (1) ONLY ID line is printed if there are hits (2)
Controls the output for sequences (in a collection) that have no hits for the options selected.
Generates HTML tags (-H) Yes No
Generates a postscript plasmid map (--ps) Yes No
Maximum number of cuts allowed in sequence (-M)
Minimum number of cuts in sequence for the enzyme to be selected (-m)

Select enzymes by magnitude of recognition site (-n)? [use example data]
3 4 5 6 7 8
The 'magnitude' of the recognition sequence depends on the number of defined bases that make up the site. Degenerate bases can also contribute:
acgt each count '1' magnitude point
yrwsmk each count '1/2' magnitude point
bdhu each count '1/4' magnitude point
n doesn't count at all
Those enzymes sequences' patterns that 'sum' to the equivalent of at least the given magnitude pass the test
The values are upwardly inclusive (5=5,6,7,8 6=6,7,8 ...)
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
tgca=4, tgyrca=5, tgcnnngca=6
tgca=4, tgyrca=5, tgcnnngca=6
Select enzymes by overhang generated (-o) 5' overhang (5) 3' overhang (3) Blunt (no overhang) (0) All (1)

Summary of site information (-s)?
Yes No
Prints the summary of site information, describing how many times each pattern matches the sequence. Those that match zero times are shown first. In Ver >2, only those that match at least once are shown in the second part (the 0 matchers are not reiterated)
Print/sort table of fragments (-F) Don't print fragments (0) Fragments printed in order of generation (unsorted) (1) Fragments sorted by size, smallest to largest (2) Both (3)
Table of actual cut sites (-S) Yes No

Ladder map of selected enzymes (-l)?
Yes No
Specify if you want a ladder map of selected enzymes, much like the GCG MAPPLOT output. Also appends a summary of those enzymes that match a few times. The number of matches that is included in the summary is length-sensitive in the distributed source code.
Print a pseudo-graphic gel map (-g) Yes No

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Low-end cutoff in number of bases for gel map (>= 10)?
You can cut off any size in 10^n increments (as you might want to cut off very large fragments if you were doing chromosomal digests).

Specify if you want linear map (-L)?
Yes No
This spews the most output (about 10x the # of input characters) and depending on what other options are specified, can be of moderate to very little use. If you want the co-translation, you'll have to specify it via the -T flag below. The Linear map also no longer shows ALL the patterns that match from the pattern file. It now obeys the same filtering rules that the Sites, Fragments, Ladder Map and other analyses do.

Linear co-translation (-T)? [use example data]
Yes No
Requests frames 1, 1-3, or 1-6 to be cotranslated with the Linear Map using 1 or 3 letter codes.
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
"-T3,3" translates Frames 1,2,3 with 3 letter labels. "-T1,1" translates Frame 1 with 1 letter labels.
"-T3,3" translates Frames 1,2,3 with 3 letter labels. "-T1,1" translates Frame 1 with 1 letter labels.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Translation in how many frames 1 frame 3 frames 6 frames
Translation code ( 1 or 3-letter) 1-letter 3-letter

Do an ORF analysis (-O)[use example data] ?
Yes No
-O 145,25 frames 1,4,5 with a min ORF size of 25 AAs -O 35x,200 frames 3 & 5 with a min ORF size of 200 AAs, with extended info. -O 2,66 frame 2 with a min ORF size of 66 AAs
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
-O 145,25 frames 1,4,5 with a min ORF size of 25 AAs -O 35x,200 frames 3 & 5 with a min ORF size of 200 AAs, with extended info. -O 2,66 frame 2 with a min ORF size of 66 AAs

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Frames to search 1 2 3 4 5 6

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Min ORF size

Do a pattern search (-p)[use example data] ?
Yes No
Name = Pattern name (1-10 chars) Pattern = <30 IUPAC characters (ie. gryttcnnngt) Err = max # of errors that are tolerated (<6).
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
Name = Pattern name (1-10 chars) Pattern = <30 IUPAC characters (ie. gryttcnnngt) Err = max # of errors that are tolerated (<6).
Pattern (<30 IUPAC character)
Max number of errors that are tolerated (<6) (-p)
Label of pattern

fieldset.legend: Search for spatial relationships between factors (-P)

xhtml:div.label:
Do a proximity search? [use example data]
Yes No
Use this option to search for spacial relationships between factors, 2 at a time (up to a total of 10).
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
-PHindIII,350,bamhi Match all HindIII sites within 350 bases of BamHI sites -PPit1,-30-2500,Tataa Match all Pit1 sites that are 30 to 2500 bases UPSTREAM of a Tataa site.
-PHindIII,350,bamhi Match all HindIII sites within 350 bases of BamHI sites -PPit1,-30-2500,Tataa Match all Pit1 sites that are 30 to 2500 bases UPSTREAM of a Tataa site.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Distance between factors?
Distance specification: [+-][lg]Dist_Lo[-Dist_Hi
+ NameA is DOWNSTREAM of NameB (default is either)
- NameA is UPSTREAM of NameB (ditto)
l NameA is LESS THAN Dist_Lo from NameB (default)
g NameA is GREATER THAN Dist_Lo from NameB

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Name of first factor (nameA)? [use example data]
NameA must be enzymes names (Rebase db)
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
HindIII, bamhi, PsiI, PvuI, RsrII, ...
HindIII, bamhi, PsiI, PvuI, RsrII, ...

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Name of second factor (nameB)? [use example data]
NameB must be enzymes names (Rebase db)
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
HindIII, bamhi, PsiI, PvuI, RsrII, ....
HindIII, bamhi, PsiI, PvuI, RsrII, ....

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Select the beginning of a subsequence from a larger sequence file. The smallest sequence that tacg can handle is 4 bases, 10 for the ladders map (-l). This allows analysis of primers and linkers.

The pattern matching is adaptive; given a small window of nondegenerate sequence, the algorithm will match very fast; if degenerate sequence is detected, it will switch to a slower, iterative approach. This results in speed that is proportional to degeneracy for most cases.

The number is truncated to a # exactly divisible by 15 (-w 100 will be interpreted as -w 90) and actual printed output will be about 20 characters wider. Also applies to output of the ladder and gel maps, so if you are trying to get more accuracy and your output device can display small fonts, you may want to use this flag to widen the output.
N bases for which hits should be pooled (integer)
Controls the output for sequences (in a collection) that have no hits for the options selected.
The 'magnitude' of the recognition sequence depends on the number of defined bases that make up the site. Degenerate bases can also contribute:
acgt each count '1' magnitude point
yrwsmk each count '1/2' magnitude point
bdhu each count '1/4' magnitude point
n doesn't count at all
Those enzymes sequences' patterns that 'sum' to the equivalent of at least the given magnitude pass the test
The values are upwardly inclusive (5=5,6,7,8 6=6,7,8 ...)

Prints the summary of site information, describing how many times each pattern matches the sequence. Those that match zero times are shown first. In Ver >2, only those that match at least once are shown in the second part (the 0 matchers are not reiterated)

If you want the co-translation, you'll have to specify it via the -T flag below. The Linear map also no longer shows ALL the patterns that match from the pattern file. It now obeys the same filtering rules that the Sites, Fragments, Ladder Map and other analyses do.
Requests frames 1, 1-3, or 1-6 to be cotranslated with the Linear Map using 1 or 3 letter codes.

parameter.name: translation

precond.code: linear_map and three_letter is not None and translation_frames is not None

Yes No

-PHindIII,350,bamhi Match all HindIII sites within 350 bases of BamHI sites -PPit1,-30-2500,Tataa Match all Pit1 sites that are 30 to 2500 bases UPSTREAM of a Tataa site.
-PHindIII,350,bamhi Match all HindIII sites within 350 bases of BamHI sites -PPit1,-30-2500,Tataa Match all Pit1 sites that are 30 to 2500 bases UPSTREAM of a Tataa site.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Use this option to search for spacial relationships between factors, 2 at a time (up to a total of 10).

comment.text: Distance specification: [+-][lg]Dist_Lo[-Dist_Hi
+ NameA is DOWNSTREAM of NameB (default is either)
- NameA is UPSTREAM of NameB (ditto)
l NameA is LESS THAN Dist_Lo from NameB (default)
g NameA is GREATER THAN Dist_Lo from NameB

interface.label:
Distance between factors?
Distance specification: [+-][lg]Dist_Lo[-Dist_Hi
+ NameA is DOWNSTREAM of NameB (default is either)
- NameA is UPSTREAM of NameB (ditto)
l NameA is LESS THAN Dist_Lo from NameB (default)
g NameA is GREATER THAN Dist_Lo from NameB

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Distance specification: [+-][lg]Dist_Lo[-Dist_Hi
+ NameA is DOWNSTREAM of NameB (default is either)
- NameA is UPSTREAM of NameB (ditto)
l NameA is LESS THAN Dist_Lo from NameB (default)
g NameA is GREATER THAN Dist_Lo from NameB

comment.text: NameA must be enzymes names (Rebase db)

interface.label:
Name of first factor (nameA)? [use example data]
NameA must be enzymes names (Rebase db)
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
HindIII, bamhi, PsiI, PvuI, RsrII, ...
HindIII, bamhi, PsiI, PvuI, RsrII, ...

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: NameA must be enzymes names (Rebase db)

comment.text: NameB must be enzymes names (Rebase db)

interface.label:
Name of second factor (nameB)? [use example data]
NameB must be enzymes names (Rebase db)
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
HindIII, bamhi, PsiI, PvuI, RsrII, ....
